title: Before 15 November 2019, will there be a lethal confrontation between the national military forces of Iran and Saudi Arabia either in Iran or at sea?
preds: It is only 3 days away.   MBS knows he has a problem concerning the survival of the Saudi Royal family and kingdom.   His recent rhetoric has been very much in favor of peace with Iran.   He seems to think a war with Iran would be suicidal.

I update my previous forecast, which was based on faulty information. During 40 years of Iran - Saudi conflict, there has been 1 direct incident between Iranian and Saudi forces: the Action of June 5, 1984 (the Saudis shot down two Iranian planes). This led to no fatalities however. Assuming that the last 40 years of conflict are totally unremarkable, i.e. the probability of what happen versus what could have happened is 50%, then we can assume a direct conflict probability of 4.2% per year. This figure is chosen as follows: a 4.2% probability means that the probability of 0 or 1 direct conflicts equals the probability of 2 or more conflicts. Of course this is a debatable choice, but well, I will buy it. Now this direct probability has to be scale down by the probability that the direct conflict will lead to a fatality, where a 50% could be a good guesstimate, yielding a 2.1% per year. Repeating the same analysis as in my previous estimation (where I assume a few enhancements of a conflict in the next few months) yields a 2.1 to 2.6% probability of a fatal conflict in the next 1.5 months. I will assume the pessimistic estimation and round it to 3%.

The conflict between Iran and Saudi Arabia has been doing on for about 40 years and there has been no direct confrontation yet. In the absence of additional information, I might assume that the scenarios of a direct and no direct conflict are equally probably, giving a 50% in 40 years of no conflict, or equivalently a 1.7% per year of direct conflict probability. The crown prince is however promoting a more aggressive form of Saudi nationalism less rooted in Islam, which probably enhances the previous probability by some factor: I will assume a factor of 2, giving a new 3.4% per year of direct conflict. However, as the possibility of Iran retaking the development of nuclear weapons increases, I would say that Saudi Arabia will be hard pressed to eventually do a preemptive attack if the US decides not to intervene. That will probably generate a larger probability during the next few years (or even the next few months). Now with the recent attack there will be too a further enhance probability. If I take a factor of 4 or 5, this gives me 14.8-18.5%, which in a period of 1.5 months approaches a 2% probability of a direct conflict. However, taking into account that the probability is certainly small, this generates a calibration problem (it's 2%, or is it 1%, or 5%?).

The Kingdom of Saudi Arabia and the Islamic Republic of Iran have never previously fought one another. Since, 1990, KSA has been involved in 8 conflicts, the latest one being the KSA intervention in Yemen, which began in 2015. The last war which the KSA fought unilaterally was in 1969. There has not to my knowledge been a fatality at sea for the KSA.  The damage to the oil and gas infrastructure has not been as catastrophic as first thought, and seems that the production will be back online fairly quickly. There is also the fact that a retaliatory strike would not have to be escalatory - the KSA could attack Iranian oil infrastructure, it does not have to attack military targets in Iran. Iran has not fought a state on state war on 1988. It often uses proxies in conflicts, which means that it does not have to risk its own military forces and the Saudis can also fight them and not the national military forces. I think if there were to be a lethal confrontation on national military forces it would be instigated by the KSA, not the IRI. Given the low base rate of this event occurring, the options for other means to punish Iran (fighting through proxies, sanctions, the US doing military action) and the short time period I am going to start fairly low with this one.

Firstly, it seems extremely likely that Iran indeed attacked Saudi oil facilities over the weekend - experts seem to agree that these attacks constitute a very well-coordinated systemic strike on Saudia Arabia's oil infrastructure and that this would have been difficult for the Iranian-backed Houthi rebels of Yemen to carry out. [1] However, despite its arch rival temporarily knocking out half of its oil production in a swift blow, I think it extremely unlikely that Saudi Arabia will retaliate against Iran unless it is reassured it has the strong backing of the U.S. - namely, that the U.S. is itself prepared to intervene militarily. Saudi Arabia is certainly aware that Iran's military is on its level and might even be stronger [2] so it will wait and see what the U.S. position is. The U.S. position is wildcard here. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo came out swinging immediately after the attacks took place by publicly blaming Iran [3] - apparently before all the facts were clear, since a U.S. forensics team sent to investigate had not yet arrived [4] and Saudi Arabia just today publicly released information on the debris of the drones/missiles used, which they said showed that the attack was clearly sponsored by Iran. In today's press conference the Saudis also stopped short of claiming that the attacks were launched from Iranian soil [5, 6] - meaning they are clearly not eager to retaliate immediately, otherwise they would've blamed Iran directly already. However, Secretary of State Pompeo today called the Iranian attack an "act of war." [7] - and yet Trump himself has not publicly blamed Iran and has instead indicated that he will wait to see what 1) Saudi Arabia says and 2) what the results of further investigations are [8]. Also, Trump just ousted his national security advisor John Bolton - an Iran hawk who apparently clashed with the President quite often - and just today named a new, more mainstream national security advisor. [9] Finally - and crucially - reports are emerging that Pentagon officials are urging the White House to show restraint in its response. [10] So, there are a couple of key signs from the U.S. indicate that it is not seriously preparing itself to intervene militarily on behalf of Saudi Arabia if Saudi Arabia chooses to retaliate. The main one is that President Trump has shown himself to be averse to starting new wars. True, he is warm toward Saudi Arabia and his recent "locked and loaded" rhetoric may seem telling, but consider that he previously extended even more bellicose threats of war to North Korea - "fire and fury" - that is, before Trump met Kim Jong Un and then "fell in love." Trump does not want to get involved in anotherwar, and the Pentagon is also apparently cautioning against it. Moreover, Trump has a new, presumably less hawkish, national security advisor. However, there are still a few signs that the probability a retaliatory attack should not be discounted: there is Secretary of State Pompeo's saber-rattling, a need by Saudi Arabia to show strength after this humiliating attack, and unconfirmed reports that Saudi planes have struck Iranian targets in Syria [11].  All in all, conflict is improbable but not insignificantly so. I do not have a base rate of whether such types of attacks have previously lead to conflicts between the two parties involved, so this determination has mostly been made on the basis of geopolitical considerations particular to this case. Saudi Arabia is ill equipped for military confrontation with Iran, which is why Iran took this action. Saudi Arabia's actions indicate that its hope is that other countries come to its defense. I concede I do not know the base rate for lethal confrontation between military forces after a non lethal incident like we had, nor would I know how to find it. However, given the brief time frame (less than 2 months), 15% seems like a conservatively high estimate of what the base rate might be. So, in this case, I am forecasting a probability under my estimated base rate based on Saudi Arabia's indications that it is averse to military confrontation.
